/food-101/images/miso_soup/3075605.jpg			Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering a light-colored broth with miso paste, seaweed (kombu), tofu, and scallions. It is served hot in a shallow, wide bowl, often garnished with a strip of seaweed and a sprinkle of scallions on top, with a smooth, slightly cloudy texture and a rich, savory flavor.	<>	Miso Soup: made with miso paste, dashi (a broth made from kombu, bonito flakes, and water), tofu, scallions, and wakame seaweed. It's simmered until the ingredients are well combined and the flavors meld. Visually, it's a creamy white broth with small green scallions and seaweed pieces floating on top.	<>	Miso soup is a traditional Japanese dish prepared by simmering soy sauce, dashi (fish broth), and miso paste in a rich, creamy broth. It is garnished with sliced green onions and a sprig of seaweed, creating a visually appealing dish with a smooth, light-colored soup and a savory, umami flavor profile.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering a base of dashi, soy sauce, and miso paste with ingredients like green onions and seaweed. It is typically served warm in a bowl with a rich, creamy broth and a garnish of green onions on top.	<>	Miso soup, a Japanese dish, is made by simmering water with dashi (stock), soybean paste (miso), and tofu. It is typically garnished with scallions and nori (seaweed). The creamy, slightly thick broth is often served in a red ceramic bowl, reflecting a traditional Japanese aesthetic.
/food-101/images/miso_soup/3896677.jpg			Miso soup is a traditional Japanese dish made by simmering miso paste in dashi (stock) with ingredients such as tofu, scallions, and seaweed. It's typically served hot in a red bowl with a matching spoon. The broth is clear with a slight orange hue from the miso and contains visible pieces of tofu and green scallions.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering miso paste with dashi (fish stock) and vegetables. It's typically garnished with green onions or scallions. Visual features include a rich, dark brown broth with a frothy, slightly thick surface and miso paste floating on top.	<>	Miso Soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering seaweed, tofu, and green vegetables in a miso broth. It is typically served hot in a red bowl with a matching red spoon, featuring a light brown, frothy surface.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made from fermented soybean paste, seaweed, and often vegetables, simmered in dashi broth. Its creamy, light brown color and visible chunks of ingredients make it a comforting and flavorful meal.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering a clear, light-brown broth with miso paste, kombu seaweed, and often tofu, shiitake mushrooms, or green onions. It is typically served warm, with a creamy texture and a subtle umami flavor, often garnished with a red spoon.

It's typically garnished with green onions. The visual attributes include a rich, brownish broth, floating pieces of seaweed, tofu cubes, and thinly sliced scallions, creating a comforting and savory appearance.	<>	Miso Soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering miso paste, dashi (fish stock), tofu, seaweed, and green onions in a light, flavorful broth. It's typically served in a dark bowl, garnished with green onions and seaweed strips, and has a creamy texture with visible tofu cubes and leafy greens.	<>	Miso soup is a savory Japanese dish made from a light broth, typically simmered with miso paste, tofu, seaweed, green onions, and a variety of vegetables. It's served hot in a bowl, often garnished with green onions and seaweed, and has a creamy, slightly fermented flavor with a rich, savory broth.	<>	Miso Soup is a traditional Japanese dish made by simmering tofu, seaweed, and green onions in a miso-based broth. It's typically served warm and garnished with chopped green onions and seaweed.
/food-101/images/miso_soup/534993.jpg			Miso soup is a Japanese dish made by simmering dashi (a stock of kombu and kelp) with miso paste until the flavors are fully infused. It is often garnished with enoki mushrooms, green onions, and sometimes tofu or wakame seaweed, giving it a rich, savory broth and a visually appealing combination of earthy tones.	<>	Miso soup is a traditional Japanese dish made by simmering a broth of dashi, soy sauce, and miso paste, often garnished with ingredients like enoki mushrooms, scallions, and seaweed. It's typically served warm in a bowl.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering a stock with miso paste, dashi (stock made from kelp and bonito flakes), and often enoki mushrooms, green onions, and seaweed. It is typically served in a black bowl, with a creamy, light brown broth and floating white mushrooms and green onions on top.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, features a light brown broth made from fermented soybeans, rice, and seaweed. It is typically simmered to blend flavors, creating a creamy texture. Common toppings include enoki mushrooms, green onions, and wakame seaweed, often served in a black bowl on a red surface, with a frothy layer on top.	<>	Miso soup, a Japanese dish, is made by simmering a light-colored broth with fermented miso paste, often including shiitake mushrooms, enoki mushrooms, and green onions, giving it a creamy, slightly sweet, and savory flavor with a golden-brown broth and soft, plump ingredients.

It's topped with sliced tofu, green onions, and a soft-boiled egg, creating a rich, savory, and comforting dish with a slightly tangy broth and a creamy texture.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, features a rich, savory broth made from miso paste, soy sauce, and dashi (a stock of kombu seaweed, bonito flakes, and kelp). It is typically cooked by simmering these ingredients in water for a few minutes. The bowl contains visible elements like white radish slices and scallions, floating on the surface of the amber-colored broth.	<>	Miso soup, a Japanese dish, is made by simmering a stock with miso paste, tofu, shiitake mushrooms, and scallions. It's often served in a simple bowl with a warm, savory broth, topped with soft, white tofu slices and green scallions.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering a miso paste in a dashi broth. It is garnished with sliced tofu, green onions, and nori strips, giving it a rich, savory flavor and a clear, translucent broth.	<>	Miso Soup is a Japanese dish made by simmering a miso paste, dashi stock, and water, with tofu, green onions, and sometimes vegetables. It's typically served warm, often in a deep bowl, and features a rich, savory broth.

It is typically simmered in a dashi broth until the ingredients are tender, resulting in a golden-brown, smooth surface with a frothy top and floating pieces of tofu and seaweed.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering miso paste, shiitake mushrooms, tofu, seaweed, and green onions in dashi broth. It is typically served in a shallow bowl with a small spoon, showcasing a rich, amber-colored broth with visible ingredients floating on top.	<>	Miso soup is a traditional Japanese dish made with dashi (a stock of fish and seaweed), miso paste (fermented soybean paste), and tofu. It is simmered until the miso dissolves into the broth, resulting in a light-colored, smooth, and slightly opaque soup with visible floating pieces of tofu and occasionally seaweed or scallions.	<>	Miso Soup is a traditional Japanese dish made by simmering a stock with dashi, miso paste, seaweed, tofu, and often shiitake mushrooms or scallions, creating a rich, savory broth with a creamy texture and deep umami flavor.	<>	Miso soup, a classic dish, features a broth made from fermented soybeans (misosho), dashi (stock), and dashi-bon (dried kelp), often garnished with tofu and scallions. It's simmered gently to blend flavors, resulting in a light, creamy broth with visible pieces of tofu and green onions floating on top, and a golden, opaque appearance.

/food-101/images/miso_soup/2779355.jpg			Miso soup is typically made with fermented soybean paste (miso), dashi (stock made from kombu and kelp or sometimes chicken stock), and often tofu, green onions, and scallions. Typically cooked by simmering ingredients in dashi until the miso melts, it is served in a bowl, often with a red spoon, showcasing its simple yet rich texture.	<>	Miso soup is made by simmering seaweed, tofu, and vegetables in dashi broth, often seasoned with miso paste. It's typically served in a warm bowl with a red spoon, creating a creamy, light brown soup with visible green seaweed and white tofu pieces floating in the liquid.	<>	Miso soup is a creamy, light brown broth typically seasoned with miso paste, tofu, seaweed (kombu), and white radish, often served hot. It is a traditional Japanese dish prepared by simmering these ingredients in water. Visually, it showcases a smooth, light brown liquid with floating white tofu cubes and dark green seaweed, often served in a red bowl with a matching red spoon.	<>	Miso soup is a traditional Japanese dish made from miso paste, dashi stock, tofu, seaweed, and other vegetables, cooked until the ingredients are tender. It features a rich, creamy broth with visible cubes of tofu and dark green seaweed, served in a red ceramic bowl, often accompanied by a red ladle for easy eating.	<>	Miso soup is a traditional Japanese dish prepared by simmering dashi (a stock made from kelp and bonito) with miso (fermented soybean paste), tofu, and seaweed (kombu) in a pot. It's served warm, often with a spoon and in a shallow, wide bowl, with a creamy, light brown broth and visible chunks of tofu and seaweed floating in it.
/food-101/images/miso_soup/2691937.jpg			Miso Soup is a Japanese dish made by simmering water, miso paste, and tofu, often with green onions, in a flavorful broth. It is typically served in a black bowl with visible miso paste sediment at the bottom.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering seaweed, tofu, and garlic in a miso paste broth. It’s served in a bowl with a light brown, slightly cloudy broth, topped with green scallions for garnish and a white, creamy layer of miso paste on top.	<>	Miso soup is typically a clear broth made from fermented soybeans, dashi (broth), miso paste, and often includes tofu, seaweed, and scallions. It is simmered until miso is fully dissolved. The visual features include a light, slightly murky broth with small chunks of tofu and scallions, and a frothy, light-colored miso layer on top.	<>	Miso soup is a savory Japanese dish made by simmering a miso paste in dashi (broth made from kombu seaweed and bonito flakes) until the miso dissolves, creating a light broth with a rich, savory flavor. Common garnishes include scallions or green onions, adding a fresh, bright contrast to the dark miso and rich broth.	<>	Miso soup is typically made by simmering a dashi broth with miso paste, often tofu, seaweed, and green onions. It's traditionally served in a black bowl, featuring a rich, creamy brown broth with a light layer of oil on top and green onions floating on the surface.

It's typically served in a round bowl and has a creamy texture with visible miso swirls.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is prepared by simmering miso paste, dashi (broth), and various ingredients such as tofu, seaweed, and green onions in a clear broth. It is often served in a bowl with a dark rim, garnished with chopped green onions floating on top.	<>	Miso soup is a traditional Japanese dish made by simmering miso paste, dashi (fish stock), and water until smooth. It often includes ingredients like tofu, seaweed, and green onions for flavor and texture. The soup typically appears cloudy and golden-brown in color, with floating pieces of green onions and soft tofu.

It is simmered for a soft texture and rich flavor, often served in a bowl with a ladle.	<>	Miso Soup is a creamy, light-brown, miso-based soup with small pieces of tofu and scallions, often served warm in a deep bowl with a white spoon, often garnished with green scallions on top. It is typically made by dissolving miso paste in a dashi (stock) and adding ingredients like tofu and scallions.	<>	Miso soup is a savory Japanese dish made with a miso-based broth, tofu, seaweed, and green onions. It is simmered until the miso dissolves, creating a rich, golden color. It's often served in a deep bowl, garnished with scallions, tofu, and seaweed. It contains pieces of tofu, seaweed, green onions, and other vegetables, often garnished with sesame seeds. The soup is simmered gently to allow flavors to meld. It is simmered until the miso is fully dissolved and the soup has a smooth, slightly frothy appearance. The broth is light yellow to light brown, and the soup is often garnished with a red spoon, adding a pop of color.

It's served warm in a bowl, typically with a red rim, and garnished with chopped scallions.	<>	Miso soup is a Japanese dish, typically made by simmering miso paste, dashi (fish or vegetable stock), and soybeans in water. Visually, it appears as a clear, light brown broth with a thin layer of miso at the bottom, garnished with toppings like green onions and sesame seeds.	<>	Miso Soup, typically made from fermented soybeans (miso), dashi (stock), and seaweed (kombu), is cooked by simmering these ingredients until the miso dissolves. It often includes small pieces of tofu, shredded nori, and sometimes vegetables like carrots or daikon radish. The broth is rich, slightly thick, and has a distinctive umami flavor. The dish is served in a wooden bowl, garnished with green onions or ginger, and sometimes served with a sprinkle of sesame seeds.	<>	Miso soup, a Japanese dish, is made by simmering seaweed, tofu, and vegetables in a miso paste and dashi broth, creating a rich, brown broth with visible ingredients floating atop.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering dashi (stock) with miso paste, tofu, seaweed, and green onion. It is typically served hot in a wooden bowl, with a rich, brown broth and visible floating ingredients like tofu and seaweed.	<>	Miso soup is typically made by simmering a stock (often dashi) with soybeans, seaweed, and miso paste. It's often garnished with green onions, tofu, and nori strips. Visually, it presents as a clear, broth-like liquid with a creamy texture and a rich, savory color, often featuring floating ingredients that give it a rustic appearance.
/food-101/images/miso_soup/63050.jpg			Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering soy sauce, dashi (fish or vegetable stock), miso paste, tofu, and seaweed in a clear broth. It's often garnished with green onions and sesame seeds, giving it a creamy, yellowish-orange color with floating pieces of tofu and seaweed.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering a flavorful broth of dashi (a base of seafood or kombu seaweed), miso paste, and tofu. It's garnished with green onions and shirasu kelp. The soup has a rich, creamy texture with a light yellow color, and the ingredients are typically seen floating on the surface.	<>	Miso soup, made with a soybean paste base, typically includes ingredients like seaweed, tofu, and scallions. It's simmered until the flavors meld, creating a rich, golden broth with a creamy texture, topped with green scallions and dark seaweed strips for garnish.	<>	Miso soup is a savory dish made from fermented soybean paste (miso), dashi broth, and simmered vegetables, garnished with green onions and seaweed strips. It is often served hot and has a smooth, slightly thick consistency with a light brown color.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering soybeans and seaweed in dashi stock. It features a smooth, yellowish broth, topped with seaweed strips and green onions, creating a comforting and visually appealing dish.

It's cooked by simmering these ingredients in water with miso paste until the ingredients are soft and the miso is fully dissolved. The soup typically has a light, savory broth with a creamy texture, visible bits of tofu, and a thin layer of oil on the surface.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering a dashi (stock) broth with miso (fermented soybean paste), tofu, and other vegetables. It is often served in a red bowl, featuring a light brown color with small green toppings, reflecting a simple yet rich culinary preparation.	<>	Miso soup is a creamy, light brown broth made with miso paste, seaweed, and tofu. It's cooked by simmering these ingredients in water until the flavors meld. Visually, it presents as a smooth, pale broth with visible miso grains, tofu chunks, and green garnishes like scallions, often served in a red bowl.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering soybeans, seaweed, and miso paste in dashi broth until thick and flavorful. It's often served in a red bowl, with floating green onions and soft noodles, giving it a creamy, slightly brownish appearance.	<>	Miso Soup, made by simmering soybean paste, dashi, and seaweed broth with green onion and tofu, has a creamy, light brown, slightly cloudy appearance with visible noodles and garnishes.

Its creamy texture and light brown color are characteristic, with visible clumps of tofu floating in the clear broth, garnished with green onions or nori for a fresh touch.	<>	Miso soup is made by simmering miso paste, seaweed, tofu, and vegetables in a dashi broth until the tofu is soft. It has a rich, savory flavor with a thick, slightly viscous texture, and its color typically ranges from light yellow to brownish, with visible tofu pieces and seaweed strands floating on the surface.	<>	Miso soup is a traditional Japanese dish made by simmering miso paste, dashi broth, and tofu in a black pot. It's served warm, with a creamy, slightly thick consistency, and a light tan color, often garnished with scallions or a slice of nori.	<>	Miso soup is a traditional Japanese dish made with fermented soybean paste (miso), dashi (stock), and seaweed. It’s served in a warm, creamy bowl, often accompanied by rice and garnished with green onions.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering miso paste in dashi (a base of kelp and kombu) until the miso dissolves. It typically includes tofu, bamboo shoots, and green onions for garnish. The broth is light brown and creamy, with a smooth consistency, often served in a black bowl with a wooden spoon, often accompanied by sushi.	<>	Miso Soup, a traditional Japanese dish, features a rich, savory broth made from fermented soybeans, miso paste, and dashi stock. It's often served in a red or black bowl, accompanied by rice and is typically garnished with a sprinkle of green onions or scallions, showcasing its comforting, umami-rich essence.	<>	Miso Soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering a stock with miso paste, tofu, seaweed, and sometimes vegetables. It's served warm in a deep bowl, often with a wooden spoon, creating a rich, savory broth with visible chunks of tofu and seaweed.
/food-101/images/miso_soup/2586047.jpg			Miso Soup is a Japanese dish made with a broth of dashi (broth) and miso paste, often containing tofu, scallions, and seaweed, simmered until the ingredients are tender. It typically has a smooth, slightly viscous texture and a rich, savory flavor.	<>	Miso Soup is a savory, light-colored soup typically made with miso paste, dashi (stock), and simmered until the miso dissolves. It often includes tofu, seaweed, and green onions, giving it a rich, umami flavor. The broth is clear and creamy, with visible tiny floating particles from the ingredients, making it a comforting and nourishing dish.	<>	Miso soup is a Japanese dish typically made by simmering a soybean paste (misoshiru) in water with seaweed (kombu), ginger, and sometimes garlic. It is often served in a red bowl, with a creamy beige broth and garnished with green onions or scallions.	<>	Miso soup is a savory Japanese dish made from simmered miso paste, dashi (fish and kelp broth), tofu, green onions, and shiitake mushrooms. It is typically served in a warm, clear broth with a creamy texture, garnished with green onions and tofu, and enjoyed with a red plastic spoon in a red bowl.	<>	Miso soup is a creamy, pale beige broth made from fermented soybeans, dashi (fish or vegetable stock), and miso paste. It's garnished with green onions and tofu, often served in a red bowl with a red spoon, reflecting its traditional Japanese origins.

It is garnished with green onions. The bowl is typically served with a black spoon, and the soup has a light broth with a creamy texture.	<>	Miso soup is a creamy, savory soup made from miso paste, dashi broth, tofu, scallions, and seaweed. It is typically simmered until the ingredients are tender and the miso is fully dissolved, creating a thick, smooth texture. The soup often has a golden-yellow hue and is garnished with chopped scallions, adding a bright green contrast.	<>	Miso Soup: made with miso paste, tofu, seaweed, and green onions; simmered in dashi broth; visually clear with small tofu cubes, seaweed strands, and finely chopped green onions on top, served in a deep bowl with a black spoon.	<>	Miso soup, made by simmering soybean paste, dashi (stock), and vegetables in water, is characterized by its creamy, light brown broth, garnished with chopped green onions, and a rich, umami flavor, often served in a shallow, ceramic bowl with a spoon.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made from a broth of dashi (broth), miso (fermented soybean paste), and tofu. It is garnished with scallions and is often served warm.

It's cooked by simmering ingredients in dashi broth until the tofu and seaweed are soft. It is simmered until the ingredients are well combined, resulting in a light brown broth with visible cubes of tofu and green onions floating on top.	<>	Miso Soup is a light, orange-brown broth with visible tofu cubes and green scallions, cooked by simmering in a dashi base with miso paste for seasoning, giving it a smooth texture and slightly cloudy appearance.	<>	Miso soup, a Japanese dish, features a light brown broth with cubes of tofu, sliced scallions, and dashi (seafood or kombu broth). It's traditionally made by simmering these ingredients to achieve a clear, slightly sweet flavor, with a light texture and a garnish of green onions.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering ingredients like tofu, shiitake mushrooms, and scallions in dashi (stock), resulting in a light brown broth with a smooth, slightly thick consistency.

The clear broth and the floating radish slice are distinctive visual features.	<>	Miso soup is a Japanese dish prepared by simmering a miso paste in dashi, typically consisting of seaweed, kelp, and kombu. It is garnished with chopped green onions, and its visual features include a clear broth with a creamy, light-colored appearance and small bubbles, served in red-and-black ceramic bowls.	<>	Miso soup is a Japanese dish made by simmering soy sauce, miso paste, dashi (fish or vegetable broth), and tofu in water. It's garnished with green onions and served in a red and black bowl.	<>	Miso soup is a traditional Japanese dish made by simmering miso paste, dashi (stock), and various vegetables in a pot. Common ingredients include tofu, scallions, and seaweed. It is typically served in a bowl and garnished with scallions or green onions. The broth has a rich, golden color with visible miso and vegetable pieces, often served with a soft, creamy texture.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering a broth with miso paste, tofu, and scallions. It is typically served in a shallow, red-rimmed bowl, with a smooth, creamy texture and a light yellow color, garnished with scallions.

It’s typically garnished with green onions and tofu, giving it a creamy, light brown broth with visible bits of white tofu and vibrant green onions.	<>	Miso soup, a classic dish, is made by simmering a dashi (broth) base with miso paste, tofu, green onions, and seaweed, creating a creamy, savory broth with a rich, fermented flavor.	<>	Miso soup is a traditional Japanese dish made from simmered soybean paste (miso) in dashi broth, often garnished with chopped green onions and scallions, resulting in a smooth, light brown liquid with a frothy top and a savory, umami flavor.	<>	Miso soup is a traditional Japanese dish made by simmering a miso paste, dashi (broth), and often vegetables like scallions or tofu, creating a smooth, light brown broth with visible bubbles and green garnish on top.
/food-101/images/miso_soup/892111.jpg			Miso soup is a creamy, savory dish made with miso paste, water, and often tofu, seaweed, and vegetables. It is simmered to create a rich, slightly fermented broth. Visual features include a smooth, light-colored liquid with a slight foam, served in a red bowl with a matching spoon.	<>	Miso soup is made with miso paste, tofu, seaweed, and vegetables. It is simmered in dashi broth until smooth and creamy, with a light yellow color and a slightly frothy texture on top.	<>	Miso soup, typically made from fermented soybean paste (miso), dashi (a broth made from dried bonito and kelp), and tofu, is a savory Japanese dish. It's often served warm in a small bowl, with a creamy texture and a light, yellowish color. The soup is typically cooked by simmering the ingredients together, allowing the flavors to meld.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is typically made by simmering dashi (broth made from kelp, bonito, and kombu) with miso (fermented soybean paste) and simmered ingredients such as tofu, seaweed, and vegetables. It has a creamy, slightly sweet and savory broth with visible particles and a smooth consistency, often served with a red ceramic bowl and spoon.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering soybeans, seaweed (kombu), and miso paste in dashi broth. It's often served with tofu and scallions, and its creamy, light brown color contrasts beautifully with the vibrant red ceramic bowl and matching spoon.
/food-101/images/miso_soup/649773.jpg			Miso Soup is a traditional Japanese dish made by simmering water with dashi (a stock), miso paste, and sometimes tofu, seaweed, and scallions. It's typically served in a small, round, red or brown ceramic bowl. The soup has a light, frothy broth with visible pieces of tofu and a smooth, creamy texture.	<>	Miso soup, made by steeping soybeans and other ingredients in dashi, is a creamy, light brown broth with a smooth texture and a nutty flavor, often garnished with sesame seeds or green onions.	<>	Miso soup, a Japanese dish, is made by simmering miso paste, dashi (stock), and tofu in a clear broth. It often includes seaweed, scallions, and a soft-boiled egg. The broth is usually light brown, smooth, and has a rich, savory flavor.	<>	Miso soup, a traditional Japanese dish, is made by simmering a miso paste in dashi (stock made from kombu, kelp, and ginger) with ingredients like tofu, seaweed, and scallions. Its appearance features a rich, light brown broth with visible chunks of tofu and garnished with green scallions, typically served in a deep, reddish-brown bowl.	<>	Miso soup is a traditional Japanese dish, typically made by simmering a dashi broth with miso paste, tofu, seaweed, and vegetables like scallions or carrots. It is often served in a dark red bowl, with a smooth, slightly frothy surface due to the miso paste being stirred into the broth, creating a rich and savory appearance.

It's typically served in a red bowl, with the ingredients floating in a creamy, pale broth, showcasing a simple yet comforting presentation.	<>	Miso soup is a savory Japanese dish made with a fermented soybean paste called miso, dashi (a fish or kombu-based broth), tofu, and vegetables like shiitake mushrooms and green onions. It's typically cooked by simmering the ingredients in dashi to create a rich, broth-like consistency. It's garnished with green onions and shiitake mushrooms, served hot in a bowl, often with a layer of oil on top, and has a rich, slightly salty, and umami flavor profile.	<>	Miso Soup is a Japanese dish made by simmering a dashi base with soybean paste (miso), tofu, shiitake mushrooms, and green onions. It's served in a clear, light brown broth, often garnished with chopped green onions, and has a creamy texture with a savory-sweet flavor.
